<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.

- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>

explanation: No controlling expressions in the function are invariant at runtime. The function contains two if statements: the first (if (NULL == *req_cls)) depends on the value pointed to by req_cls at each call and is not a compile-time constant; the second (the strcmp-based conjunction testing method against two HTTP-method strings) depends on the runtime method argument and is not invariant. There are no loop (for/while/do) or switch controlling expressions in the function that could be constant, and the code does not create an intentional infinite loop. The preprocessor conditional (#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701) is a compile-time conditional, not a C-language runtime controlling expression covered by MISRA C Rule 14.3, so it does not constitute a violation of the rule. Therefore there are no fragments that require further investigation for Rule 14.3 in this function.
